text: Any other questions of Brian? Brian, can I just ask you about peat roads and how they're standing up in the summer heat? Because our rural areas have got quite a few peat roads. And then I'll get Janet to, once you've answered that question, I'll get Janet to ask you something.
speaker: clairestpierre

text: Sure, sure. Yep. So peat roads, yep, they operate on a fine sort of moisture balance. And when we get a really dry summer, then the land beside the road dries out and that sucks moisture out from under the road and the peat shrinks. So the road on top of the peat is almost like a water, you know, a raincoat.  And it means that for most of the time, the moisture content in that peat is reasonably stable until we get a drought type situation. And then the surrounding land dries out, the peat under the road dries out and shrinks. And if the peat is anything from sort of  you know, three to five to 10 metres deep, then, you know, there's nothing we can do to stop that shrinkage. I know that if farm drains are not close to the road or farm drains, if they're not cleaned out, so they're left where they are so that water levels remain high, then that can partly protect the road and reduce that peat shrinkage. But we, you know, last summer we had a lot of  shrinkage and we've we repaired the worst pieces in some places we had to put up signs and temporary speed limits like Collins Road is one of those and say hey you need to slow down because we cannot we simply cannot afford to fix all of these roads. I think this year we've probably allocated three to four hundred thousand dollars to go in and smooth  some of those roads which are out of shape. But if we do end up with another dry summer, we'll get another $300,000 or $400,000 worth of damage from that drying that we'll have to repair as well. So it is a risky business, but sometimes the only option we've got is to do some light smoothing and put up those signs and warn people to slow down.
